body:
> it will allow string identifiers for configs contained in plugins as well as objects

My 2c - disallow this.

Flat configs went a long way to making configs "just javascript" and less magical. Allowing string references to plugin definitions would be bringing back a magical thing.

It's also a difficult / impossible thing to statically analyse for to help catch bad code ahead of the lint run. For example right now it's very easy to use TS to sanity check the config and catch typos like `js.configs.reccomended` - but it wouldn't be really possible to do the same for a dynamic string.

Additionally many plugins have intentionally not shipped flat configs via their `plugin` object and instead only make them available via import paths. They did this to make the backwards-compatibility story easier. So allowing string references would create a weird disjoint in the ecosystem that these plugins couldn't be used with.

It's worth noting that we already have extends in the flat config ecosystem in userland via the  `tseslint.config` utility:

https://typescript-eslint.io/packages/typescript-eslint#flat-config-extends

Many people love it and rely on it to simplify their configuration. I built it because it was such a lifesaver for setting up typescript-eslint's own internal flat config.

Example usage:
https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/blob/main/eslint.config.mjs#L360-L370

body:
> Flat configs went a long way to making configs "just javascript" and less magical. Allowing string references to plugin definitions would be bringing back a magical thing.

We already do this for rules and processors, so I'm not sure why configs would be any different.

> Additionally many plugins have intentionally not shipped flat configs via their `plugin` object and instead only make them available via import paths. They did this to make the backwards-compatibility story easier. So allowing string references would create a weird disjoint in the ecosystem that these plugins couldn't be used with.

Right, and this is what adds to the confusion. Users are complaining that there are too many ways to mix and match configs. This would help shepherd towards a more consistent approach. Another downside is that ESLint itself has limited visibility as to where the configs are coming from. By being able to trace a config back to a plugin, we have a lot more information when something goes wrong.

> It's worth noting that we already have extends in the flat config ecosystem in userland via the `tseslint.config` utility

I'm aware...and this is another thing that people are complaining about. :smile: Yet another way to do things.

My initial thought was that maybe we should do something similar: make a utility that can implement `extends` rather than adding it natively, but I'm sensitive to asking people to install another package just to get something so many believe should be built-in.

> We already do this for rules 

Rules are entirely different because they are object keys. It's expected that they are stringly referenced because there isn't another option without ditching objects for config.

> and processors

True, though very very few people are configuring processors by hand, from my experience. So it's a mostly invisible part of the system to many users.

---

My advice would be to remove the magic where possible to make things easier to understand and easier to statically analyse.

Let rules be the only thing that's stringly referenced.

From the reactions on my above post I'm not the only one who feels this way.

---

As a motivating example.  Stringly referenced things are very hard to add jsdoc and types for. Member expressions and imports are dead simple to do it for.

For example anyone consuming the `typescript-eslint` package will see intellisense that describes the config and provides a link to the docs. This is going to be VERY hard to wire up for a loose string reference.
